message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass suggests a pituitary adenoma, which can cause visual disturbances, headaches, and hypopituitarism. Among the options, erectile dysfunction is commonly associated with hypopituitarism. Galactorrhea is also associated with pituitary adenomas, but it is not specific to this type of mass. Coarse facial features and abdominal striae are associated with Cushing’s syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol secretion from an adrenal mass or by long-term use of glucocorticoids. There is no indication of Cushing's syndrome in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass and visual disturbances suggest a pituitary adenoma. Among the options, only erectile dysfunction is associated with pituitary adenoma, specifically, a decrease in testosterone levels due to the adenoma’s pressure on the pituitary gland. Galactorrhea is also associated with pituitary adenoma, but it occurs when the adenoma produces prolactin, which does not seem likely in this case. Coarse facial features and abdominal striae are associated with Cushing’s syndrome, which is caused by adrenal gland adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and MRI findings suggest a pituitary adenoma. Among the options, erectile dysfunction can result from low levels of testosterone if the tumor compresses the pituitary gland and reduces testosterone secretion. Galactorrhea and coarse facial features can also result from pituitary adenoma if it secretes prolactin or growth hormone, respectively. Abdominal striae are associated with Cushing’s syndrome, which is caused by excessive cortisol production. However, the patient does not exhibit any symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass suggests a pituitary adenoma, and the double vision and impaired peripheral vision are signs of optic nerve dysfunction. Among the options, only erectile dysfunction is associated with pituitary adenoma due to its effect on the secretion of gonadotropins. Galactorrhea is also associated with pituitary adenoma but is not mentioned in the patient's symptoms. Coarse facial features and abdominal striae are associated with Cushing's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the MRI scan of the head suggest a pituitary tumor, specifically a prolactinoma. Erectile dysfunction is a common symptom of hyperprolactinemia. Galactorrhea and coarse facial features are related to other types of pituitary tumors, while abdominal striae are related to Cushing’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the intrasellar mass suggest a pituitary tumor. The impaired peripheral vision points to damage to the optic chiasm caused by the tumor. Of the options, only erectile dysfunction is associated with a pituitary tumor, specifically one that affects the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). Galactorrhea is more commonly associated with prolactin-secreting pituitary tumors. Coarse facial features and abdominal striae are more commonly associated with Cushing's syndrome caused by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-secreting pituitary tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass suggests a pituitary adenoma, which can cause visual disturbances and headaches. Among the options, only erectile dysfunction is related to pituitary adenoma because it can affect production of gonadotropins, which regulate testosterone production. Galactorrhea is also a symptom of pituitary adenoma, but it’s not mentioned in the scenario. Coarse facial features and abdominal striae are more suggestive of Cushing's syndrome, which is caused by hyperactivity of the adrenal cortex, not the pituitary gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass and visual disturbances suggest that the patient has a pituitary adenoma. Erectile dysfunction is a common symptom associated with pituitary adenoma due to decreased levels of testosterone. Coarse facial features and abdominal striae are more commonly seen in Cushing's syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol production from the adrenal glands, not from a pituitary adenoma. Galactorrhea is commonly seen with prolactinomas, but is not a common symptom of non-functioning pituitary adenomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an intrasellar mass, which is most likely a pituitary adenoma. Visual disturbance, particularly impaired peripheral vision, is associated with pituitary adenomas. Among the options, only erectile dysfunction is associated with pituitary adenomas, specifically those that affect the production of gonadotropins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass suggests a pituitary adenoma, which can cause visual disturbances and headaches. Among the options, only erectile dysfunction is associated with pituitary adenomas, specifically those that affect the secretion of gonadotropins. Galactorrhea is associated with prolactin-secreting adenomas, coarse facial features with acromegaly, and abdominal striae with Cushing’s syndrome.
